content.rendered:
Login flows, you use a regular flow with them, then you assign them to a profile, that’s the Login flow part, but why use them? What‘s the point of them? What do you gain? Can you explain some use cases? Well, there are quite a few, for internal and external users, and I’m going to tell you about some of those now.

What are they?

First off, what are they and what do they do? Well, Login Flows are flows that connect to individual profiles, or you can connect one flow to many profiles one by one, and they fire when a user logs in. They are used to collect data, verify information, show a message, or prevent login (more on that, I promise it’s not a crazy idea).

When would you use them?

Well, there are tons of reasons why. First off, remember that Login Flows are a single Flow that you tie to each profile you want to have use it individually. Therefore, you don’t have to have EVERYONE using it, and you could have different Login Flows for different users based on the use case.

  • You can use them for new users, to collect their information, Eg. Phone, address, company, other onboarding details. This way you can make sure that you collect the their information. Either forcing them to enter the info to login or making the message show every time they login until they do.
  • Use Login Flows for showing an upcoming maintenance message, when will the system be updated and what will be updated, to make sure your users know things will be changing and what, no way they can say they didn’t know if they are warned every time they login.
  • Login Flos work with authentication. You know how you have that 5 digit code with 2 factor authentication that goes to your email or your phone based on if you register your phone or not? You can let users pick which one to send the code to with a login flow vs having it always be one or the other.
  • Require a security question to login that they have to answer with Login Flows. You can have a user agree to terms and conditions when logging into a community.
  • You can LOCK USERS OUT. This is an awesome way to prevent users from accessing Salesforce or a Community while you do a deployment and update the system. This way you don’t have to worry about disrupting current user.

So many ways to use them! I bet the wheels are turning in your head now…

How to Build One

First let’s look at the basics, a users must first login to Salesforce to access a Login Flow, so they have to be authenticated. This isn’t a new Username and Password page to authenticate users, it’s an additional step after that.

Second, users can’t do anything until they finish the Login Flow, so don’t make it a ginormous task for them that will become frustrating and overly time consuming, they might give up and say they don’t want to use Salesforce, not what we want. KISS Keep It Simple Silly.

Login Flows usually have a screen component, this is where you have the message and/or fields for them to complete. If you have to check if they have already completed information, you’ll also need a Record Lookup component. The thing to remember is it’s just a Flow in the beginning.

Once we have our Flow, we want to make it a Login Flow, to do that we go to Setup and search for Login Flow in the quick find, here we can click new and assign the Flow to a Profile, and viola! We have created a Login Flow, not so scary right? Things sound so difficult because they are mysterious sometimes.

Examples

Community User Terms and Conditions

Very common situation in communities, you have external users that you want to have agree to Terms & Conditions. You don’t want them to do this every time, just if they haven’t agreed to the most recent Ts&Cs. A great way to do this, is with a Login Flow!

There is your flow, if it looks intimidating, don’t worry we are going to break it down.

Variables

  • DocSignedID

SObject Variables

  • Terms_And_Conditions_SObjVar –> Custom Object “Legal Documents” Legal_Documents__c
  • SignedTAndCs –> Custom Object “Legal Document Agreements” Legal_Document_Agreements__c

Formulas

  • CurrentUserID – {!$User.Id}
  • TermsAndConditionsURL – {!$Label.Terms_And_Conditions_URL}

Now that you have the basics of what makes it up, you probable want to know how they fit together, well, here we go….

Build Flow

  1. First thing we want to do is lookup the Legal Documents to see what the most current one is. We want to sort them Descending, and take only the first one, save it in an SObjectVariable. Since we use multiple fields on the screen, we want to capture all of those now. Save it in the Terms_And_Conditions_SObjVar
    • Name
    • Version
    • Terms
    • Date Active **Field we sort by to get the most recent version
    • Id
  2. Next we want to lookup the User’s signed Terms that use that Legal Document Id. Record Lookup Legal Document Agreements WHERE the Document__c = Terms_And_Conditions_SObjVar.Id AND User__c = CurrentUserId. Make sure to check the allow for null checkbox, because they might not have signed the current version. We want to collect the Id, Date, User, Document Variables. Save them in the SignedTAndC SObject Variable.

Screens

  1. Now we need to make a decision, did we find a Signed Terms and Conditions record for this User that uses the most recent Terms and Conditions version? In other words, did that last Record Lookup have any results? If it was null, we want to show them the screen, if it wasn’t null, then they can enter the community. Just two options, very straight forward.
  2. So here we have them going to the screen, where we display the Terms and Conditions Text. We display the text from the Legal_Document__c record and then 2 radio buttons, I accept and I decline, again, keeping it simple. No need to over complicate things here.
  3. Next, we need to check if they accepted the terms or not. For that we have our decision looking at the Choice from the screen and if the Accepted choice was selected.
  1. If the Accepted choice wasn’t selected, we go back to the screen, if it was selected, we go to create a Legal Document Agreement record (DocSignedId) and the user enters the community.

As you work with the flow, you can modify it to make it more customized to your needs, here is the same flow, with different text that displays when a user is accepting the terms and conditions for the first time vs accepting an updated version, but if you don’t need it more complex, don’t make it more complex.

Login Flow

Now we need to make this flow a login flow…

  1. Go to Setup – Security Controls – Login Flows
  2. Click New
  3. Select the flow you just created
  4. Select the profile you want to go through the flow when they login. WARNING: DO NOT SELECT YOUR PROFILE OR THE SYSTEM ADMIN PROFILE
  5. Click Save.


And you’re all set now!

Prevent Users from Logging In

Similar to our last flow, we want to make a flow with a screen, but this time, there is far less we need to do.

  1. we just need a screen, and put our Salesforce is unavailable from X until Y for maintenance.
  2. Then on that screen you want to uncheck the finish and previous buttons.
  3. Now assign your flow to the profiles you want to prevent from accessing Salesforce.
  4. Most importantly, don’t forget to take it down when you finish maintenance 🙂

I hope you had fun learning about Login Flows and have some cool ideas about how to use them in the future and awesome stuff you can do with them in your projects. Give it a go in your sandbox or dev org and hit me up on Twitter, @MeighanSF or the comments here to let me know how it went for you.

Additional Resources

  • Login Flow Examples
  • Create a Login Flow with Visualforce
  • Stage Flow

***March 2021 Update***

Now Deployable

You can use Metadata API to add or edit login flows. To delete login flows, use the Login Flow page.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Login Flow Deployment
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Update for Login Flow Deployments with Spring 21 and their new availability in the metadata API making them deployable!

jetpack-related-posts.title: Talkin’ Bout Stages in Flow
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: All about the Stage Variable within flows and how to use it so that you can have that fancy shmacy path at the top of your screens - and guess what, it's a single little lightning component that gets to be re-used and for the flow side, everything is declarative!

jetpack-related-posts.title: Community Sharing Part 2: Guest Page Visibility
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: This post we expore guest user visibily in Experience Cloud. Every Community has a Guest User and Guest User Profile. A guest is someone that can see your community before they login - an Unauthenticated user. Each time a community or portal is created, Salesforce auto-creates a guest user profile…

img.alt_text: Community Sharing part 2_ Guest Page Visibility

jetpack-related-posts.title: List Custom Settings
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: What is a Custom Setting?  We talked about Hierarchy Custom Settings in the Keep Clean Validation Rules with Custom Settings post, which let you set a default field value for the organization, then you can assign a value to a Profile or User.  List Custom Settings are a bit different, they don't…

jetpack-related-posts.title: Mass Create Community Users
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Learn all about Mass Community User creation in this post, with everything from mappings to links to the User Template to Welcome email send.

img.alt_text: Featured Image: Mass Create CC Users

jetpack-related-posts.title: CMS Connect 18 Updates
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: My experience at Connections 18 and updates to CMS Connect for your Lightning Community, learn all about it here!
